content.raw: Just some warnings which probably came from another PR
content.html: Just some warnings which probably came from another PR

content.raw:
Good point. Our SDF interface is not ideal. Other XML parsers have nicer ways to quickly get elements with one line of code. We can look into improving SDF.

Matching protobuf to SDF also implies that SDF is the only source of data for our messages. Another user, who may not use SDF would find the nesting overly expressive.
content.html:
Good point. Our SDF interface is not ideal. Other XML parsers have nicer ways to quickly get elements with one line of code. We can look into improving SDF.

Matching protobuf to SDF also implies that SDF is the only source of data for our messages. Another user, who may not use SDF would find the nesting overly expressive.

Yeah that's a good point, the declaration of messages can get crowded. But as far as the API for accessing fields goes, I guess the same happens to SDF:

if (gpsElem->HasElement("position_sensing"))
{
  auto positionElem = _sdf->GetElement("position_sensing");

  if (positionElem->HasElement("horizontal"))
  {
    auto horizontalElem = positionElem->GetElement("horizontal");

    if (horizontalElem->HasElement("noise"))
    {
      auto noiseElem = horizontalElem->GetElement("noise");

      ...
    }
  }
}

I'm fine with it the way it is, I was just wondering how much we want the messages to match SDF. If in the future we do add a sibling to <position_sensing><horizontal><noise>, on protobuf we will have to add a sibling to PositionSensing->horizontal_noise instead.

content.raw: Done, and jenkins kicked off.
content.html: Done, and jenkins kicked off.

content.html: Added

update.description: Support conversions between SDF and protobuf for more sensors.
update.title: Added more sensor messages

content.html:
Protobuf messages and XML have different purposes and different syntax. Nesting in XML is useful for readability, but nesting in a message doesn't buy us much. We'd have an extra layer of messages that would have to be transmitted over the wire, and any code would also become more complex.

Example:

message GPSSensor
{ 
  message PositionSensing
  {
    message Horizontal
    {
      optional SensorNoise noise = 1;
    }
    optional Horizontal horizontal = 1;
  }

  optional PositionSensing position = 1;
}

To use this, we'd have to write (note that every level of nesting is now reflected in the code that uses the message):

if (msg.has_position())
{
  msgs::GPSensor::PositionSensing &pos = msg.position();
  if (pos.has_horizontal())
  {
    msgs::GPSensor::PositionSensing::Horizontal &horz = pos.horizontal();
    if (horz.has_noise())
    {
      msgs::GPSensor::PositionSensing::SensorNoise *noise = horz.noise();
    }
  }
}

We could make the change, but it feels like extra complexity for marginal benefit.

content.raw: Can we change the expected values to be all different? If we're setting vertical from horizontal for example, this wouldn't pick it up.
content.html: Can we change the expected values to be all different? If we're setting vertical from horizontal for example, this wouldn't pick it up.

content.raw:
In SDF this is more [nested](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=sensor#sensor_gps), should we try keeping the same hierarchy? Maybe SDF was nested because other elements might be added to horizontal / vertical in the future?

`position_sensing` > `horizontal` > `noise`
content.html:
In SDF this is more nested, should we try keeping the same hierarchy? Maybe SDF was nested because other elements might be added to horizontal / vertical in the future?

position_sensing > horizontal > noise

content.raw:
This is a very interesting point.

Could it be that we are doing something [not recommended](https://github.com/protobuf-c/protobuf-c)? like this: 

"""
It is not recommended to export the symbols in the code generated by protoc-c in a stable library interface, as this will embed the protobuf-c ABI into your library's ABI. 
"""

If this is the case, that could explain the situation: since we could be embedding the ABI of the message in the library, these two changes are breaking our library ABI and the text about the 'backwards-compatibility' applies to binaries.
content.html:
This is a very interesting point.

Could it be that we are doing something not recommended? like this:

""" It is not recommended to export the symbols in the code generated by protoc-c in a stable library interface, as this will embed the protobuf-c ABI into your library's ABI. """

If this is the case, that could explain the situation: since we could be embedding the ABI of the message in the library, these two changes are breaking our library ABI and the text about the 'backwards-compatibility' applies to binaries.

content.raw:
"You can add new fields to your message formats without breaking backwards-compatibility; old binaries simply ignore the new field when parsing. So if you have a communications protocol that uses protocol buffers as its data format, you can extend your protocol without having to worry about breaking existing code."

Source: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/overview

@\_jrivero\_ , does this mean:

1. Our ABI checker is a bit too strict for protobuf extensions, or
2. The protobuf documentation is referring to API, and not ABI compatibility, or
3. something else?
content.html:
"You can add new fields to your message formats without breaking backwards-compatibility; old binaries simply ignore the new field when parsing. So if you have a communications protocol that uses protocol buffers as its data format, you can extend your protocol without having to worry about breaking existing code."

Source: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/overview

@_jrivero_ , does this mean:

  1. Our ABI checker is a bit too strict for protobuf extensions, or
  2. The protobuf documentation is referring to API, and not ABI compatibility, or
  3. something else?
